Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Experiments and Theory of Nonequilibrium Processes in Turbulent Combustion

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511834 (Raman, University of Michigan-Ann Arbor)/1511025 (Clemens, University of Texas-Austin)

Fluid flows are complicated under conditions found in engines and power plants, due to fuel combustion. The research team proposes to investigate the fluid flow phenomenon by using the state-of-art computer simulation techniques with the help of advanced laser-based measurements. The results will be used for constructing models for the flame and flow predictions under such complex conditions. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the research. The PIs also propose K-12 activities.

A novel multi-scale modeling approach is proposed to elucidate energy transfer mechanisms between scales in low-Mach number and highly turbulent reacting flows with premixed and non-premixed injections. For the experimental effort, advanced, laser-based diagnostic tools are proposed: PIV (particle imaging velocimetry) and Rayleigh and Raman scattering for velocity field and scalar/species concentration measurements, respectively. The experimental data will provide large ensembles of statistical data that have direct bearing on the presence and impact of non-equilibrium in the velocity and scalar fields. They will also be used for comparison with result from CFD (Computational Fluid Dynamics) simulation, based on DNS (Direct Numerical Simulation), to understand the interaction between combustion and turbulence and between phenomena occurring at various length scales in turbulent combustion. Furthermore, by using time and length scales characterizing non-equilibrium generating impulses, the structure and evolution of turbulent flames will be studied. A variational multiscale approach will be used as a framework for modeling non-equilibrium turbulent combustion, where the energy transfer across impulse-generating scales will be modeled explicitly. A small-parameter expansion based unsteady dissipation rate model will be developed. The experiments will be critical to the modeling effort since a far larger range of conditions can be investigated than is possible with DNS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project represented a collaborative effort between the University of Michigan and UT Austin to explore the modeling of "rare events" in turbulent combustion by using a dynamical systems perspective. For example, we are looking for means to predict rare events such as jet-engine blowout or gas-turbine flashback. Our collaborator conducted large-eddy simulation (LES) modeling and we (UT Austin) conducted validation experiments. The experiments involved making high-speed laser measurements of velocity in a turbulent non-premixed jet flame to compute Lyapunov exponents. Lyapunov exponents give us an idea of how chaotic the flow is. More specifically, Lyapunov exponents are related to the rate of divergence of two points in a high-dimensional phase space. Our assumption is that flows that are more chaotic are more susceptible to the growth of perturbations, and in turn will be more likely to lead to global instabilities.

We explored two different measures of chaos. The first was finite-time Lyapunov exponents, which give us local information and thus enable us to investigate flow-flame interaction. These results showed that the reaction zone is a region of high divergence of particle trajectories, and hence is a region that could lead to chaotic behavior. The second measure of chaos was used to investigate the global system dynamics. This was achieved by using a time-series method with successive time delays as it can be proven to imbed the higher-dimensional dynamics. This method was applied to time-resolved velocity data, and could effectively quantify regions of high sensitivity to disturbances. This technique was used to validate the simulations by using the same analysis techniques for both the experimental and LES data, and this showed that the time-series method could reconstruct similar magnitude maximum Lyapunov exponents. This finding shows that our method validates the perturbation method that was used in the LES to compute Lyapunov exponents, and thus give us new insight into the global dynamics of turbulent flames.

This research program helps us to understand the structure and stability of turbulent flames, which has potentially important impact on energy and propulsion technologies. A graduate student received training in combustion science, turbulence, non-linear dynamics and laser diagnostics. Undergraduate students, including those from under-represented groups (female) received training in experimental design and fluid mechanics. We also began a new initiative to aid in the education of under-represented minority students by creating a cooperative-research program with a local historically black university.
